case_name: assessee firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.110 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No.110 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 25, 1955, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 57/X of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 25, 1955 of Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 57/X of 1954

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 25, 1955, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 57/X of 1954. A. Palkhivala and I. N. Shroff, for the Appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 24, 1960 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay

facts.text: Appeal against judgment of High Court of Bombay answering question against assessee firm

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay answering the question submitted to it. against the assessee firm who is the appellant before us,

facts.text: Appellant is assessee firm, respondent is Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: against the assessee firm who is the appellant before us, the respondent being the Commissioner of Income-tax. The appeal relates to the assessment year 1949-50, the accounting year ended on July 25, 1948.

facts.text: Assessment year 1949-50, accounting year ended July 25, 1948

anchor.surface_text: the respondent being the Commissioner of Income-tax. The appeal relates to the assessment year 1949-50, the accounting year ended on July 25, 1948. The appellant is a firm doing the business of importing dates from abroad and selling them in India.

facts.text: Appellant firm does business of importing dates from abroad and selling in India

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a firm doing the business of importing dates from abroad and selling them in India. During the accounting year the appellant imported dates from Iraq. At the relevant time the import of dates by steamers was prohibited by two notifications dated December 12, 1946,

facts.text: During accounting year appellant imported dates from Iraq

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year the appellant imported dates from Iraq. At the relevant time the import of dates by steamers was prohibited by two notifications dated December 12, 1946, and June 4, 1947, but they were permitted to be brought by country craft.

facts.text: Import of dates by steamers prohibited by notifications dated December 12, 1946 and June 4, 1947, permitted by country craft

anchor.surface_text: At the relevant time the import of dates by steamers was prohibited by two notifications dated December 12, 1946, and June 4, 1947, but they were permitted to be brought by country craft. Goods which had been ordered by the appellant were received partly by steamer and partly by country craft.

facts.text: Goods ordered by appellant received partly by steamer and partly by country craft

anchor.surface_text: Goods which had been ordered by the appellant were received partly by steamer and partly by country craft. Consignments, which were imported by steamer and were valued at Rs. 5 lacs were confiscated by the Customs Authorities under s. 167, item 8 of the Sea Customs Act but under s. 183 of that Act the,

facts.text: Consignments imported by steamer valued at Rs. 5 lacs confiscated by Customs under s.167 item 8 Sea Customs Act

anchor.surface_text: Consignments, which were imported by steamer and were valued at Rs. 5 lacs were confiscated by the Customs Authorities under s. 167, item 8 of the Sea Customs Act but under s. 183 of that Act the, appellant was given an option to pay fines aggregating Rs. 1,63,950 which sum on appeal was reduced to Rs. 82,250.

facts.text: Under s.183 Sea Customs Act, option to pay fines Rs.1,63,950, reduced on appeal to Rs.82,250, paid by appellant, dates released

anchor.surface_text: appellant was given an option to pay fines aggregating Rs. 1,63,950 which sum on appeal was reduced to Rs. 82,250. This sum was paid and the dates were released. On the sale of the goods certain profits accrued out of which it sought to deduct Rs. 82,250 paid as penalty on ordinary principles of commercial accounting.

facts.text: On sale of goods, profits accrued, appellant sought to deduct Rs.82,250 paid as penalty

anchor.surface_text: This sum was paid and the dates were released. On the sale of the goods certain profits accrued out of which it sought to deduct Rs. 82,250 paid as penalty on ordinary principles of commercial accounting. The Income-tax Officer disallowed this claim which was also disallowed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the deduction claim

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed this claim which was also disallowed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. On appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal this sum was held to be allowable by a majority of two to one.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed the claim

anchor.surface_text: which was also disallowed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. On appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal this sum was held to be allowable by a majority of two to one. At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court for its opinion-

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held sum allowable by majority 2 to 1

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal this sum was held to be allowable by a majority of two to one. At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court for its opinion- Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case,

facts.text: At instance of respondent, Tribunal referred question to High Court

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court for its opinion- Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payment of Rs. 82,250 is an allowable expenditure under Section 10 (2) (xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Question referred: Whether Rs.82,250 allowable under s.10(2)(xv) IT Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payment of Rs. 82,250 is an allowable expenditure under Section 10 (2) (xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act? The High Court held that the above amount of Rs. 82,250 could not be said to have been paid for salvaging the goods but was paid as a penalty incurred in consequence of an illegal,

facts.text: High Court held Rs.82,250 not allowable, paid as penalty for illegal act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the above amount of Rs. 82,250 could not be said to have been paid for salvaging the goods but was paid as a penalty incurred in consequence of an illegal, act on the part of the appellant and was therefore not an allowable item under s. 10 (2) (xv) of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appellant firm appealed to Supreme Court by special leave

arguments.court_reasoning: Cited cases concern double jeopardy or separate proceedings under different acts, not deductibility under Income-tax Act

arguments.claim: Liability incurred under s.167 item 8 and s.183 Sea Customs Act is a penalty for infraction of law regarding prohibited import

anchor.surface_text: These sections show the punishments provided for the breach of the prohibitions in regard to importation or exportation of goods under ss. 18 and 19 the power of the Customs Authorities to give an option to pay in lieu of confiscation and how the penalties are to be imposed. Therefore when the appellants incurred the liability they did so as a penalty

arguments.claim: Cited cases like Maqbool Hussain, Shewpujanrai etc. are distinguishable as they deal with double jeopardy or no prosecution after customs proceedings, not tax deductibility

anchor.surface_text: The contention now raised before us is quite different. What is to be decided in the present case is whether the penalty which was paid by the appellant firm was an allowable deduction within s. 10 (2) (xv) of the Income-tax Act which provides S. 10 (2) (xv) any expenditure not being in the nature of capital

arguments.claim: Penalty for breach of law is not deductible under s.10(2)(xv) as not wholly and exclusively laid out for purpose of business, following English cases like Strong v Woodifield, Warnes, Von Glehn

anchor.surface_text: The words for the purpose of such business have been construed in Inland Revenue v. Anglo Brewing Co. Ltd. 5 to mean for the purpose of keeping the trade going and of making it pay. The essential condition of allowance is that the expenditure should have been laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business.

arguments.claim: Distinction between personal penalty and penalty against goods (in rem) is erroneous; any penalty for infraction of law not deductible under s.10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that unless the penalty is of a nature which is personal to the assessee and if it is merely ordered against the goods imported it is an allowable deduction. That, in our opinion, is an erroneous distinction because disbursement is deductible only if it falls within s. 10 (2) (xv)

court_response_anchor.surface_text: iscussed above. In our opinion, numberexpense which is paid by way of penalty for a breach of the law can be said to be an amount wholly and exclusive

arguments.court_reasoning: Must satisfy test of wholly exclusively for business; infraction of law not incidental to trade; public policy prevents deduction

arguments.claim: No expense paid by way of penalty for breach of law can be wholly and exclusively for business purposes; against public policy to allow deduction of penalties

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that a penalty paid for an infraction of the law, even though it may involve no personal liability in the sense of a fine imposed for an offence committed, is wholly and exclusively laid for the business in the sense as those words are used in the cases that have been discussed above.

holdings.text: when the appellants incurred the liability they did so as a penalty for an infraction of the law but it cannot be said that the money which they had to pay was number paid as a penalty and in fact under s. 167 8 it was a penalty.

anchor.surface_text: These sections show the punishments provided for the breach of the prohibitions in regard to importation or exportation of goods under ss. 18 and 19 the power of the Customs Authorities to give an option to pay in lieu of companyfiscation and how the penalties are to be imposed. Therefore when the appellants incurred the liability they did so as a penalty for an infraction of the law but it cannot be said that the money which they had to pay was number paid as a penalty and in fact under s. 167 8  it was a penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sea Customs Act ss. 18, 19, 167 item 8, 183 provide for penalties and option in lieu of confiscation for prohibited imports; payment falls under penalty provision.

holdings.text: The contention now raised before us is quite different. What is to be decided in the present case is whether the penalty which was paid by the appellant firm was an allowable deduction within s. 10 2 xv of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention now raised before us is quite different. What is to be decided in the present case is whether the penalty which was paid by the appellant firm was an allowable deduction within s. 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act which provides S. 10 2  xv  any expenditure  number being in the nature of capital expenditure or personal expenses of the assessee  laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business, profession or vocation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cited precedents like Maqbool Hussain, Shewpujanrai concern double jeopardy or separate proceedings under different statutes, inapplicable to income-tax deductibility under s.10(2)(xv).

holdings.text: a penalty imposed for breach of the law during the course of trade cannot be described as [a commercial loss]. If a sum is paid by an assessee conducting his business, because in conducting it he has acted in a manner, which has rendered him liable to penalty it cannot be claimed as a deductible expense.

anchor.surface_text: an expenditure is number deductible unless it is a companymercial loss in trade and a penalty imposed for breach of the law during the course of trade cannot be described as such. If a sum is paid by an assessee conducting his business, because in conducting it he has acted in a manner, which has rendered him liable to penalty it cannot be claimed as a deductible expense. It must be a companymercial loss and in its nature must be company- templable as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenditure deductible only if commercial loss wholly and exclusively for business per s.10(2)(xv); penalties fail as not incidental to trade, following Strong & Co. v. Woodifield, Von Glehn, Warnes.

holdings.text: Infraction of the law is number a normal incident of business and therefore only such disbursements can be deducted as are really incidental to the business itself. They cannot be deducted if they fall on the assessee in some character other than that of a trader.

anchor.surface_text: Such penalties which are incurred by an assessee in proceedings launched against him for an infraction of the law cannot be called companymercial losses incurred by an assessee in carrying on his business. Infraction of the law is number a normal incident of business and therefore only such disbursements can be deducted as are really incidental to the business itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deductible expenses must be incidental to business; law violations are not normal business incidents.

holdings.text: That, in our opinion, is an erroneous distinction because disbursement is deductible only if it falls within s. 10 2 xv of the Income-tax Act and number such deduction can be made unless it falls within the test laid down in the cases discussed above and it can be said to be expenditure wholly and exclusively laid for the purpose of the business.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that unless the penalty is of a nature which is personal to the assessee and if it is merely ordered against the goods imported it is an allowable deduction. That, in our opinion, is an erroneous distinction because disbursement is deductible only if it falls within s. 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act and numbersuch deduction can be made unless it falls within the test laid down in the cases discussed above

holdings.reasoning_summary: Whether personal or in rem (against goods), penalty payments must satisfy s.10(2)(xv) test of being wholly and exclusively for business; distinction irrelevant.

holdings.text: In our opinion, number expense which is paid by way of penalty for a breach of the law can be said to be an amount wholly and exclusively laid for the purpose of the business. [...] anything done which is an infraction of the law and is visited with a penalty cannot on grounds of public policy be said to be a companymercial expense for the purpose of a business or a disbursement made for the purposes of earning the profits of such business.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that a penalty paid for an infraction of the law, even though it may involve numberpersonal liability in the sense of a fine imposed for an offence companymitted, is wholly and exclusively laid for the business in the sense as those words are used in the cases that have been discussed above. In our opinion, numberexpense which is paid by way of penalty for a breach of the law can be said to be an amount wholly and exclusively laid for the purpose of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Penalties for illegal acts, irrespective of personal liability, fail s.10(2)(xv) as not for business purpose; deductible only if commercial and not against public policy.

anchor.surface_text: Lee v. Butler  1  in which the transaction was described by Lord Esher, M.R., as Hire and Purchase Agreements and Helby v. Matthews  2  in which the House of Lords distinguished the former case on the ground that in that case there was a binding contract to buy and not merely an option to buy, without any obligation to buy.

precedents.cited_proposition: locus classicus on hire-purchase agreements where there was a binding contract to buy
precedents.cited_holding: transaction described as Hire and Purchase Agreements

anchor.surface_text: Helby v. Matthews  2  in which the House of Lords distinguished the former case on the ground that in that case there was a binding contract to buy and not merely an option to buy, without any obligation to buy. Both these cases were decided in terms of Factors Act of 1889  52 53 Viet. c. 45, s. 9 .

precedents.cited_proposition: distinguished Lee v Butler; hire-purchase where only option to buy, no binding obligation
precedents.cited_holding: no binding obligation on hirer to buy

precedents.citation: Maqbool Hussain etc. v. The State of Bombay etc. 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of his argument counsel for the appellant firm referred to Maqbool Hussain etc. v. The State of Bombay etc.  1  and to the following passage at p. 742 where Bhagwati, J., said- Confiscation is no doubt one of the penalties which the Customs Authorities can impose but that is more in the nature of proceedings in rem than proceedings in personam

precedents.case_name: Maqbool Hussain v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: confiscation is proceedings in rem, option to pay fine in lieu
precedents.cited_holding: Confiscation is no doubt one of the penalties... in lieu of confiscation such fine as the officer thinks fit

precedents.citation: Shewpujanrai Indrasanrai Ltd. v. The Collector of Customs Ors. 2

anchor.surface_text: Similar observations were made by S. K. Das, J., in Shewpujanrai Indrasanrai Ltd. v. The Collector of Customs Ors.  2  where it was said that a distinction must be drawn between an action in rem and proceeding in personam and that confiscation of the goods is a proceeding in rem

precedents.case_name: Shewpujanrai Indrasanrai Ltd v Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between in rem and in personam; confiscation in rem
precedents.cited_holding: confiscation of the goods is a proceeding in rem and the penalties are enforced against the goods

precedents.citation: Leo Roy Frey v. The Superintendent, District Jail, Amritsar 1

precedents.case_name: Leo Roy Frey v Superintendent District Jail Amritsar
precedents.cited_proposition: view same as Maqbool Hussain on in rem proceedings

precedents.citation: Thomas Dana v. The State of Punjab 2

anchor.surface_text: Leo Roy Frey v. The Superintendent... and Thomas Dana v. The State of Punjab  2  is the same. In Dana case  2  Subba Rao, J., said at p. 298- If the authority concerned makes an order of confiscation it is only a proceeding in rem

precedents.case_name: Thomas Dana v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: confiscation is proceeding in rem, penalty against person is in personam
precedents.cited_holding: If the authority concerned makes an order of confiscation it is only a proceeding in rem and the penalty is enforced against the goods

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Warnes Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Warnes Co.  1 , the assessee who carried on the business of oil exporters were sued for a penalty on an information exhibited by the Attorney-General under the Sea Customs Consolidation Act

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v Warnes & Co

precedents.cited_holding: a penal liability... cannot be regarded as a loss connected with or arising out of a trade

anchor.surface_text: Rowlatt, J., relying on the observation of Lord Loreburn, L. C., in Strong Co. v. Woodifield  2  said at p. 452- but it seems to me that a penal liability of this kind cannot be regarded as a loss connected with or arising out of a trade.

precedents.cited_proposition: losses must be connected with trade in sense incidental to trade itself
precedents.cited_holding: only such losses could be deducted as were connected with it in the sense that they were really incidental to the trade itself

precedents.cited_holding: test from Strong v Woodifield applied; expenses not admissible except for legal advice

precedents.cited_proposition: damages for libel not allowable as not exclusively for business
precedents.cited_holding: fell on the assessee in his character of a calumniator... only remotely connected with his trade

precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure for mixed purposes not wholly and exclusively for business

precedents.cited_proposition: damages for dishonest breach of contract not allowable

anchor.surface_text: These sections show the punishments provided for the breach of the prohibitions in regard to importation or exportation of goods under ss. 18 and 19 the power of the Customs Authorities to give an option to pay in lieu of companyfiscation and how the penalties are to be imposed. anchor.surface_text: an expenditure is number deductible unless it is a companymercial loss in trade and a penalty imposed for breach of the law during the course of trade cannot be described as such. It must be a companymercial loss and in its nature must be company- templable as such.
